(Ord. 1730.  Passed 3-27-72.)
808.03  MINIMUM PERSONNEL AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   Each ambulance service serving the City shall provide the followingminimum
personnel and minimum qualifications:
   (a)   There shall be one driver and one attendant for each ambulance vehicle
andeach emergency rescue vehicle.
   (b)   Each driver and each attendant shall have been certified by the
OhioDepartment of Education to have taken the emergency victim and rescuecourse
of the Trade and Industrial Education Service, and a certified copy orphotocopy
of such certificate shall be filed with the Director of Public Safety.
   (c)   Each driver and each attendant shall have a certificate of completion
of notless than eighty hours of the standard and advanced first-aid course of
theAmerican Red Cross, and a certified copy or photocopy of such
certificateshall be filed with the Director.
   (d)   No driver or attendant shall have been convicted of a felony or
themisdemeanor of vehicular homicide within the ten years next
precedingemployment by a licensed ambulance service within the City.
   (e)   Each driver shall hold a valid Ohio chauffeur's license and a
certified copy orphotocopy of such license shall be filed with the Director.
(Ord. 1730.  Passed 3-27-72.)
808.04  EMPLOYMENT BY CONTRACT.
   Employment of an ambulance service in the City shall be by contract.
(Ord. 1730.  Passed 3-27-72.)
808.05  VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall operate or cause to be operated an ambulance vehicle
oremergency rescue vehicle, except the City rescue truck, within the
City,without full compliance with this chapter and without a contract with the
City.
(Ord. 1730.  Passed 3-27-72.)
808.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
thischapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be
finednot more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or
subsequentoffense, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree
and shallbe fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned
not morethan sixty days, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
eachday during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.

812.01  BILLIARD AND POOL ROOMS, PING PONG AND SHUFFLEBOARD; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a billiard room, pool room, bowling alley, game room
or video room in the City without first obtaining a license therefor from the
City Manager.
(Ord. 2252.  Passed 3-12-90.)
812.02  LICENSE FEES.
   (a)   There is hereby fixed a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
for the first pool or billiard table or alley and five dollars ($5.00) for each
additional pool or billiard table or alley per year upon the business of
conducting billiard or pool rooms and bowling alleys in the City.  There is
hereby fixed a license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each pinball or video
game or machine and four dollars ($4.00) for each additional identical pinball
or video game or machine, upon the business of conducting pinball or video
games in the City.
   (b)   The license fees set forth in subsection (a) hereof shall be payable
in a lump sum by January 30 of each year at the office of the City Manager.
(Ord. 2252.  Passed 3-12-90.)

812.06  CIRCUSES, MENAGERIES AND CARNIVALS.
   (a)   Each person desiring to conduct, stage or give a circus, menagerie or
carnival, for which money or reward is demanded or received, shall first obtain
a written license from the City Manager.  The fee for such license shall be two
hundred dollars ($200.00) per week.
   (b)   In addition to the license fee, the applicant for a license to
conduct, stage or give such exhibition shall give notice to the City Manager,
in writing, stating the dates of the performances and the location at which
they are to be presented.  The City Manager shall give his or her consent to
the issuance of such license, if he or she deems that the location is suitable
for the purpose, that it will properly accommodate the patrons and that the use
of said location will not unduly burden the Police and/or Fire Divisions.
(Ord. 2252.  Passed 3-12-90.)

   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
CHAPTER 816
Continuity of Cable Television

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Franchises - see Tables of Special Ordinances (Preliminary Unit),
Table A
   Interrupting or impairing television - see Ohio R.C. 2909.04
   "Property" defined to include cable television service - see GEN. OFF.
606.01(o)
   Unlawful interest in contracts - see GEN. OFF.
606.17
   "Services" defined to include cable television service - see GEN. OFF.
642.01(a), (r)
   Theft of services prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
642.02
816.01  SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter may be known and cited by its short title which is the
"Continuity of Cable Television Services Ordinance."
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.02  INTERPRETATION OF CHAPTER.
   (a)   This chapter shall be construed in light of applicable State and
Federal laws, rules and regulations.
   (b)   Wherever permissible, this chapter shall be construed with as much
flexibility as possible, so that the City may accomplish its goals of
protecting the health, safety and welfare of the residents with respect to
providing continuity of cable services in certain instances.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.03  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   As of the effective date of this chapter (Ordinance 2156; passed August 27,
1987), it shall apply to any and all existing or subsequently authorized cable
operators and/or cable franchisees who operate a cable system within all or a
portion of the City.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.04  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Assignment of a franchise" or "transfer of a franchise" means:
      (1)   The transfer of ten percent of the voting rights of a corporate
franchisee;
      (2)   The transfer of ten percent of the voting rights of a corporate
franchisee general partner;
      (3)   A change in the general partners of a franchise;
      (4)   A sale of ten percent of a cable television system (based on the
system's net worth) from one person to another; or
      (5)   A sale or transfer of a majority of a cable system's property or
assets from one person or franchisee to another person.
   (b)   "Cable operator," tough not necessarily a franchisee, means any person
or group of persons who or which:
      (1)   Provides cable television service over a cable system and directly
or through one or more affiliates owns a significant interest of at least ten
percent in such cable system; or
      (2)   Otherwise controls or is responsible for, through any arrangement,
the management and operation of such a cable system.
   (c)   "Cable service" means:
      (1)   The one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or
other programming service; and
      (2)   Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection
of such video programming or other programming service; or
      (3)   Two-way addressable cable.
   (d)   "Cable system" or cable television system" means a facility consisting
of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation,
reception and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which
includes video, voice or data programming, and which is provided to multiple
subscribers within the City.  However, such term does not include the
following:
      (1)   A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of
one or more broadcast stations;
      (2)   A facility that serves only subscribers in one or more multiple
unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management, unless such
facility uses a public right of way;
      (3)   A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in
part, to the provisions of Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, except
that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes
of Section 621 (c) of the CCPA, codified as 47 USC 541) to the extent that such
facility is used in the transmission of video, voice or data programming or
service directly to subscribers; or
      (4)   Any facility of any electric utility used solely for operating such
electric utility.
   (e)   "CCPA" means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984.
   (f)   "City" means the City of Geneva, Ohio, a municipal corporation in and
of the State of Ohio, in its present incorporated form, or in any later
reorganized, consolidated, enlarge or reincorporated form, and its duly
authorized officials acting on its behalf.
   (g)   "City Manager" means the existing or succeeding chief administrative
officer of the City or his or her designate.
   (h)   "Council" means the present governing body of the City or any
successor to the legislative powers of the present Council.
   (i)   "Franchise" means the initial authorization, or a subsequent renewal
granted under either a franchise or an ordinance, to construct, operate and
maintain a cable television system in all or part of the City.
   (j)   "Franchise expiration" means the date of expiration or the end of the
term of a franchise, as provided under the franchise.
   (k)   "Franchisee" means a person who is awarded a franchise by Council to
construct, operate and maintain a cable television system in all or part of the
City.  A franchisee is by nature and definition a cable operator.
   (l)   "Other programming service" means information that a cable operator or
franchisee makes available to all subscribers generally.
   (m)   "Person" means any individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership, association of two or more persons having a joint common
interest, governmental agency or other legal entity.
   (n)   "Proposed abandonment of cable service," or "proposed withdrawal of
cable service" or "proposed cessation of cable service" means the anticipated,
contemplated, imminent or expected (either voluntary or involuntary)
disruption, discontinuance, desertion or removal of a cable operator's or cable
franchisee's operation and provision of cable services from all or part of the
City for a projected period exceeding three months in duration.
   (o)   "Revocation," "termination" or "nonrenewal" means an official act of
the City whereby Council removes, repeals or rescinds a previously approved
authorization of any cable franchisee to conduct the operation of a cable
television system within the City.
   (p)   "Subscriber" means a person receiving service delivered over a cable
television system.
   (q)   "USC" mans United States Code.
   (r)   "Video programing" means programming provided by, or generally
considered comparable to programming provided by, a television broadcast
station.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.05  INTENT.
   (a)   The City declares that it has a responsibility to its residents to
take all appropriate measures in order to ensure that no portion of the City is
threatened or faced with a disruption, interruption or discontinuance of cable
service because of the actions of any cable operator or cable franchisee, or
the actions of the City itself.
   (b)   In addition to the principles and ideals enumerated in subsection (a),
the City also expresses that its intent covers the following:
      (1)   Providing for continuity of services in the event of Municipal
acquisition of a cable system within the City;
      (2)   Providing for continuity of services in the event of a proposed
abandonment, withdrawal or cessation of cable service by a cable operator or
cable franchisee;
      (3)   Providing for continuity of services in the event of the
revocation, termination or nonrenewal of a cable franchise;
      (4)   Providing for continuity of services in the event of an expiration
of a franchise;
      (5)   Preventing disruption of cable service which would provide a
hardship on those residents of the City who rely on cable services, including
the emergency alert override, as their primary or secondary source for
information;
      (6)   Assuring cooperation and accountability of a cable operator or
franchisee with respect to the continuous and uniterrupted provision of cable
services during the period of time such operator or franchisee serves residents
of the City;
      (7)   Providing for the health, safety and welfare of the residents of
the City by ensuring the continuous and uninterrupted provision of cable
services and by establishing interim or transitional procedures for a cable
operator or franchisee to abide by in the event of:
         A.   Municipal acquisition of a cable system within the City;
         B.   The abandonment, withdrawal or cessation of cable service by a
cable operator or franchisee;
         C.   The revocation, cancellation or nonrenewal of a cable franchise;
or
         D.   The expiration of a franchise;
      (8)   Preventing the interruption or cessation of cable services which
would disrupt or eliminate the diversity of programming choices enjoyed by
subscribers of cable television, and thereby restricting their ability to
receive information; and
      (9)   Providing a benefit to any cable operator or franchisee in that
such an operator or franchisee would have an orderly transition process to
transfer the operation, construction and maintenance of a cable system from one
cable operator to another operator or person, thereby reducing the likelihood
of any administrative or judicial action being taken.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.06  SCOPE OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall be effective within the geographical limits of the City.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.07  MUNICIPAL ACQUISITION OF CABLE SYSTEM.
   (a)   The City hereby reserves the right, at any time, to explore and, if
found after a thorough examination to be in the City's est interest, to make an
offer to purchase or otherwise acquire any cable operator's or franchisee's
cable system operating within the City.
   (b)   If the City makes an offer to acquire a cable system within the City,
and the cable operator or franchisee accepts such an offer, the operator or
franchisee and the City should enter into an agreement detailing the steps and
measures that will be implemented in order to transfer control of the cable
system from the operator or franchisee to the City.
   (c)   During the period between the purchase and actual transfer of the
cable system, the cable operator or franchisee shall do everything in its power
to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous, uninterrupted cable service
regardless of the circumstances.
   (d)   Independent of any agreement executed between the City and the
operator or franchisee, Council may direct and require the operator or
franchisee to continue to operate the system and provide cable services for a
period of up to nine months in order to allow Council sufficient time to
establish an administrative procedure for operating a cable system and
providing cable services to the residents of the City.
   (e)   In the interim nine-month period, during which the cable operator or
franchisee continues to provide cable services to all subscribers, the operator
or franchisee is entitled to all revenue collected, except for any sums owed
(including franchise fees or taxes to the City or to other persons.
   (f)   The Municipal acquisition and the details of the transition agreement
shall conform to and be in compliance with all State laws and rules.
   (g)   The acquisition of a cable system by the City shall not prevent the
City from subsequently transferring or reselling the system to another cable
operator or franchisee.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.08  PROPOSED ABANDONMENT, WITHDRAWAL OR CESSATION OF CABLE SERVICE.
   (a)   A cable operator or franchisee shall not abandon, withdraw or cease to
provide cable service to all or part of the City without the prior written
consent of Council.  Such written consent not be unreasonably withheld. 
Moreover, if such written consent is withheld, then the City must state its
reasons, in writing, and must take whatever steps are necessary to minimize the
potential burden to the cable operator or franchisee.
   (b)   At any time a cable operator or franchisee decides or proposes to
abandon, withdraw or cease the provision of cable services to all or of the
City, then such cable operator or franchisee must notify the City, in writing,
at least ninety days before such action is to take effect.  The notice shall be
sent to both the City Manager and the City Solicitor.
   (c)   Upon such notice, Council shall, within forty-five days, advise the
cable operator, in writing, as to whether it intends to give its written
consent and to invoke the continuity provisions of this chapter.
   (d)   If Council does give its written consent and does invoke the
continuity provisions of this chapter, then the affected cable operator or
franchisee shall do everything in its power to ensure that all subscribers
receive continuous, uniterrupted cable service regardless of the circumstances.
   (e)   Council may direct and require the cable operator or franchisee to
continue to operate the system for a period of up to twelve months in order to
allow Council time to secure another operator or franchisee for the operation
of the cable system.
   (f)   In the interim twelve-month period, during which the affected cable
operator or franchisee continues to provide cable to al subscribers, the
operator or franchisee is entitled to all revenue collected, except for any
sums owed (including franchise fees or taxes) to the City o to other persons.
   (g)   The provisions of this section shall also apply in cases where a sale,
transfer or assignment of a franchise will result in the immediate or imminent
abandonment, withdrawal or cessation of cable from all or a portion of the
City.
   (h)   If Council does give its written consent, but does not invoke the
continuity provisions of this chapter then the affected cable operator or
franchisee shall take immediate action to remove all cable system property from
the City's rights of way within 210 days of the effective date of such
abandonment, withdrawal or cessation.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.09  REVOCATION, TERMINATION OR NONRENEWAL OF FRANCHISES.
   (a)   Upon a declaration of default and revocation, termination or
nonrenewal of a cable franchise, the affected franchisee shall do everything in
its power to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous, uninterrupted
cable service regardless of the circumstances.
   (b)   In such a case, Council may direct and require the affected franchisee
to continue to operate the system for a period of up to fifteen months in order
to allow Council time to award a new franchise or to allow the affected
franchisee to complete the sale of the cable television system.
   (c)   In the interim fifteen-month period during which the affected
franchisee continues to provide cable services to all subscribers, the affected
franchisee is entitled to all the revenue collected, except for any sums owed
(including franchise fees and taxes) to the City or to other persons;
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.10  EXPIRATION OF FRANCHISES.
   (a)   If any franchisee's franchise has not been revoked or terminated by
the franchise expiration date, and if the City and a franchisee have not
entered into a new franchise, then the City shall not direct or require, for a
period of at least six months, a franchisee to cease providing cable to all or
part of the City.
   (b)   Conversely, under such circumstances, the affected franchisee shall do
everything in its power to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous,
uninterrupted service.
   (c)   In order to ensure the continuity of cable television service and to
prevent any possible laps in service to subscribers, Council may direct and
require the affected franchisee to continue to operate the system for a period
up to six months in order to allow time for approval of a new franchise, or to
allow Council to take any prudent and reasonable action it determines to be in
the best interests of the residents of the City.
   (d)   In the interim six-month period during which the affected franchisee
continues to provide cable services to all subscribers, the affected franchisee
is entitled to all the revenue collected, except for any sums owed (including
franchise fees and taxes) to the City or to other persons.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.11  SALE OF FRANCHISES.
   (a)   Section 627 of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 (CCPA)
(codified as 47 USC 547) prescribes the procedures for conditions of sale in
certain circumstances, including those noted in this chapter.  Consequently,
the City hereby adopts the procedures of Section 627 of the CCPA as its own.
   (b)   For purposes of clarity and convenience, Section 627 of the CCPA reads
substantially as follows:
      (1)   If a renewal of a franchise held by a franchisee is denied and the
City acquires ownership of the cable television system or effects a transfer of
ownership of the cable television system to another person, any such
acquisition or transfer shall be:
         A.   At a fair market value, determined on the basis of the cable
television system as a growing concern, but with no value allocated to the
franchise itself; or
         B.   In the case of any franchise existing on December 29, 1984 (the
effective date of the CCPA), at a price determined in accordance with the
franchise if such franchise contains provisions applicable to such an
acquisition or transfer.
      (2)   If a franchise held by a franchisee is revoked for cause and the
City acquires ownership of the cable television system or effects a transfer of
ownership of the system to another person, any such acquisition or transfer
shall be:
         A.   At an equitable price; or
         B.   In the case of any franchise existing on December 29, 1984 (the
effective date of the CCPA), at a price determined in accordance with the
franchise if such franchise contains provisions applicable to such an
acquisition or transfer.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.12  NONCOMPLIANCE, FAILURE TO ENFORCE.
   A cable operator or franchisee shall not be excused from complying with any
of the terms or conditions of this chapter, or amendments thereto, by reason of
any failure of the City upon one or more occasions to insist upon or to seek
compliance with such terms and conditions.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.13  ASSESSED CHARGES OR LIQUIDATED DAMAGES FOR BREACH OF FRANCHISE.
   In instances where a franchise provides for assessed charges or liquidated
damages for a breach or violation of the franchise, then such assessed charges
or liquidated damages shall operate as a separate and independent remedy for
the City to pursue.  Such assessed charges or liquidated damages, when
permitted, shall not be used by the City until the City first attempts to
resolve the matter in a nonadministrative or nonjudicial manner.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
816.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter shall
be subject to the imposition of any or all sanctions or punishments provided
for by State law.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2156.  Passed 8-27-87.)
CHAPTER 824
Garage Sales
824.01   Garage sale defined.

824.05   Merchandise.

824.07   Interpretation.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Auctions - see Ohio R.C. 1302.41, Ch. 4707
   Christmas tree sales - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4551
   Theft - see GEN. OFF.
642.02,
642.03
   Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
642.22
   Peddlers and solicitors - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 848
824.01  GARAGE SALE DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "garage sale" means a public sale of personal
property in the City.
(Ord. 2137. Passed 9-8-86.)
824.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE; DISPLAY.
   (a)   No person shall conduct a garage sale in the City without first
obtaining a license therefor and complying with the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   Application for such a license must be made in person in the office of
the City Manager.
   (c)   The City Manager shall issue the license in compliance with this
chapter. Such license shall include the name of the person conducting the sale,
or at whose premises the sale is conducted, and the date and location of the
sale. There shall be no fee for the license.
   (d)   The license must be displayed in a manner and place clearly visible
from the street upon which the residence is situated.
(Ord. 2137. Passed 9-8-86.)
824.03  HOURS; SUNDAY SALES.
   Garage sales shall not commence before 9:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday
and before 12:00 p.m. on Sunday and must terminate by sundown. Garage sales are
permitted on every day of the week subject to obtaining a permit.
(Ord. 1702. Passed 3-22-71; Ord. 2775. Passed 8-12-02.)
824.04  FREQUENCY.
   No person shall conduct more than two garage sales on his or her premises in
any one calendar year. A person may have two three-day sales or one six-day
sale.
(Ord. 1814. Passed 11-11-74.)
824.05  MERCHANDISE.
   Garage sales shall offer only used and unwanted items of personal property
owned by the resident of the property where the sale is held. No new
merchandise shall be offered for sale and no new merchandise from other sources
shall be brought in and offered for sale.
(Ord. 1702. Passed 3-22-71.)
824.06  ADVERTISING; SIGNS.
   (a)   Garage sales may be advertised in newspapers or other news media.
   (b)   A sign, not greater in size than three feet by three feet, may be
used. However, no sign shall be placed on the public right-of-way or upon
utility poles. No lighted sign shall be used. The sign shall be removed when
the use for which the sign has been erected is completed.
(Ord. 2137. Passed 9-8-86.)
824.07  INTERPRETATION.
   It is not the intention of this chapter to change or amend the Zoning Code
of the City.
(Ord. 1702. Passed 3-22-71.)
824.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
CHAPTER 826
Gas and Oil Wells
826.01   Definitions.
826.02   Permit required; insurance.
826.03   Compliance with regulations required.
826.04   Additional requirements.
826.05   Classification of wells.
 
826.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Oil and gas - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1509
   Oil and gas well log - see Ohio R.C. 1509.10, 1521.05
   Underground storage of gas - see Ohio R.C. 4161.01, 4161.05
826.01  DEFINITIONS.
As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Burn off" means the flaring or burning of escaping gas from an
approved and secured blowoff pipe.
   (b)    "Condensate" means liquid hydrocarbons that were originally in the
gaseous state in the reservoir.
   (c)    "Driller" means the person responsible for the actual drilling
operation.
   (d)    "Gas" means all natural gas and all other fluid hydrocarbons not
defined as oil, including condensate.
   (e)    "Oil" means crude petroleum oil and all other hydrocarbons,
regardless of gravity, that are produced in liquid form by ordinary production
methods, but does not include liquid hydrocarbons that were originally in a
gaseous state in the reservoir.
   (f)    "Producer" means the owner of a gas or oil well.
   (g)    "Well" means any bore hole, whether drilled or bored for production,
extraction or injection of any gas or liquid mineral, excluding potable water
to be used as such, but including natural or artificial brines and oil field
waters.
(Ord. 2056. Passed 3-12-84.)
826.02  PERMIT REQUIRED; INSURANCE.
   Before any equipment can be moved on site, the driller or producer shall
submit a plot plan and State permit to the City. The driller or producer shall
also submit to the City, prior to commencing drilling operations, evidence of a
comprehensive liability insurance policy in accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 2056. Passed 3-12-84.)
826.03  COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS REQUIRED.
   All gas and/or oil wells shall at all times be in compliance with the
provisions of the Ohio Revised Code and the ordinances of the City, regarding
such activities, and with the rules and regulations of the Ohio Department of
Natural Resources, Division of Oil and Gas.
(Ord. 2056. Passed 3-12-84.)
826.04  ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   In addition to the requirements of Sections
826.02 and
826.03, all wells shall be in compliance with the following
   (a)    All equipment shall be muffled to minimize noise impact on adjacent
properties.
   (b)    Lights shall be shielded to prevent glare onto residential
properties.
   (c)    Notice shall be given to the Fire Division prior to any burn off.
Fire extinguishers shall be maintained on the site during drilling or burn-off
operations.
   (d)    No equipment or material that is not required for the daily operation
of the well shall be stored on the site.
   (e)    Any producing equipment at the wellhead or the storage tanks shall be
surrounded by a dike equal to thirty feet by sixty feet by three feet. This
dike shall not be breached.
   (f)    A culvert pipe shall be installed prior to constructing a driveway
and approved by the City Engineer and/or the Street Commissioner. The pipe
shall be a minimum of twelve inches in diameter and a minimum of forty feet in
length.
   (g)    All waste products produced while drilling shall be contained in
surface containers or double lined pits and shall be disposed of properly.
   (h)    No propane or LP gas shall be used on drilling sites, unless approved
by the Fire Division.
   (i)    In addition, the Fire Division may impose other regulations
concerning burn off of by-products and/or the safety and health of residents
within the City.
   (j)    Plugging and/or capping of wells shall be done in accordance with
Chapter 1509 of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (k)    A permanent sign, a minimum of twenty-four inches by twelve inches,
shall be posted at the entrance to the well site. The sign shall contain the
property owner's name, the well owner's name, emergency telephone numbers and
the State permit number.
   (l)    All equipment and vehicles shall be free of mud prior to entering on
the highway so that no deposit is left on the roadway. Any deposit left on the
roadway shall be immediately removed.
   (m)    No brine shall be disbursed on any City roadway without the express
consent of the Street Commissioner.
   (n)    Upon completion of all drilling operations and the removal of all
mobile equipment, the permit holder shall notify the Street Commissioner and/or
the City Engineer, who will inspect the site and the adjacent roadway. Any
roadway damage attributable to the drilling operation or the egress of the
drilling equipment shall be repaired at the owner/ operator's expense. The
roadway shall be returned to a condition substantially the same as before
commencement of the drilling operation.
   (o)    Upon acceptance by the Street Commissioner and/or the City Engineer
of the roadway condition and/or repair, the bond shall be released.
(Ord. 2056. Passed 3-12-84.)
826.05  CLASSIFICATION OF WELLS.
   Wells of less than 1,000 feet in depth, the products from which are used by
residences on the site, shall be deemed Class I wells. All other wells shall be
deemed Class II wells.
   (a)    Class I wells. Class I wells shall comply with the following
requirements
      (1)    Such wells shall be located a minimum of 200 feet from any
structure unless this requirement is waived by the Planning Commission due to a
hardship, but under no circumstances shall it be less than 100 feet.
      (2)    All equipment and the wellhead shall be secured.
      (3)    All emergency access shall be provided in a manner approved by the
Fire Chief.
      (4)    A performance bond or cash in the amount of two thousand dollars
($2,000) shall be deposited with the City prior to the start of any work on the
site. Such deposit shall ensure restoration of the roads and rights of way to
their original condition after drilling and may be released by the City upon
determination of compliance.
      (5)    The driller or producer shall submit to the City, prior to
commencing drilling operations, evidence of a comprehensive liability insurance
policy in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000). The terms of such
policy shall provide for continuous coverage against both bodily injury and
property damage until all drilling and construction have been completed and
shall be subject to the approval of the City.
   (b)    Class II wells. Class II wells shall comply with the following
requirements
      (1)    Such wells shall be located a minimum of 200 feet from any
structure unless this requirement is waived by the Planning Commission due to a
hardship, but under no circumstances shall it be less than 100 feet.
      (2)    The wellhead and storage tanks shall be securely fenced. The fence
shall be of noncombustible material and shall be not less than six feet high
with barbed wire on the top and a locked gate. No structure shall be located
within thirty feet of such fence. A minimum ten-foot wide access road capable
of supporting eighteen tons and of all weather composition shall be provided to
the tank batteries. In addition, access and equipment shall be provided for
fire equipment during drilling and until the well is in operation.
      (3)    A performance bond or cash in the amount of two thousand dollars
($2,000) shall be deposited with the City prior to the start of any work on the
site. Such deposit shall ensure restoration of the roads and rights of way to
their original condition after drilling and may be released by the City upon
determination of compliance.
      (4)    The driller or producer shall submit to the City, prior to
commencing drilling operations, evidence of a comprehensive liability insurance
policy in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000). The terms of such
policy shall provide for continuous coverage against both bodily injury and
property damage until all drilling and construction have been completed and
shall be subject to the approval of the City.
(Ord. 2056. Passed 3-12-84.)
826.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000) for a first offense and not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent offense. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Od. 2056. Passed 3-12-84.)
CHAPTER 828

828.01   Proximity of pumps, tanks, etc. to street line.

   CROSS REFERENCES

of the City or within ten feet thereof.
(Ord. 664.  Passed 9-25-33.)
828.99  PENALTY.

misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 848
Peddlers and Solicitors
848.01   Uninvited peddling and soliciting prohibited; exceptions.
848.02   Sales from public ways and places.
848.03   Temporary business permit; fee and duration.
 
848.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
   Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
   Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
   Sale of goods and services within right of way of  Interstate and other
State highways - see Ohio R.C. 5517.07
   Littering - see GEN. OFF.
660.03
  848.01   UNINVITED PEDDLING AND SOLICITING PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   The practice of going in and upon private residences in the City by
solicitors of magazine subscriptions or other items of merchandise, peddlers,
hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of merchandise or services,
not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of such
private residences, for the purpose of soliciting orders for magazine
subscriptions or the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or services, and/or
disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same, is hereby declared to be a
nuisance and is prohibited.
   (b)   This section shall not be construed to prohibit the owner of any
product of his or her own raising, or the manufacturer of any article
manufactured by him or her, from selling, by himself or herself, any such
product or article.
   (c)   This section shall not be construed to prohibit persons from
soliciting door to door for the distribution of religious literature.
(Ord. 1323.  Passed 5-12-58.)
848.02  SALES FROM PUBLIC WAYS AND PLACES.
   (a)   Application of Section. Except as otherwise provided in Sections
1252.03(b) and
1252.04(b) of the Zoning Code, sales from public ways and places shall be
regulated as provided in this section.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (b)   License Required; Fee. No person shall sell or offer for sale in, on
or from any street, sidewalk or alley in the City, or from any motor vehicle or
other type of vehicle, whether motor propelled or not, located upon any street,
sidewalk or alley in the City, any goods, merchandise, foodstuffs or other
article or thing, until he or she has obtained a license therefor from the City
Manager. The fee for such license shall be eighty dollars ($80.00) for
commercial enterprises and fifty dollars ($50.00) for nonprofit organizations.
(Ord. 2264.  Passed 4-23-90; Ord. 2874.  Passed 6-13-05; Ord. 3112. Passed 6-
10-13.)
   (c)   Hours; Sound Reproducing Devices. No person shall sell or offer for
sale in, on or from any street, sidewalk or alley in the City, or from any
motor vehicle or other type of vehicle, whether motor propelled or not, located
upon any street, sidewalk or alley in the City, foodstuffs or other articles or
things of any kind at any time other than between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and
9:00 p.m.
   No such person shall produce or allow to be produced, by means of any sound
reproducing device, unnecessarily loud or continual sounds in such a manner as
to disturb the good order and quiet of a neighborhood in connection with such
sales or offers to sell.
   (d)   Exceptions. This section does not apply to:
      (1)   The sale of produce from any stand or mobile unit constructed or
existing off the traveled portion of any street, sidewalk or alley in the City
and for which a permit has been issued pursuant to the ordinances of the City;
or
      (2)   The sale of produce or articles in or on amusement grounds, parks,
halls and other duly licensed public places.
(Ord. 1464.  Passed 1-22-62.)
848.03   TEMPORARY BUSINESS PERMIT; FEE AND DURATION.
   (a)   Permit Required.  Every person, whether principal or agent, who
proposes to conduct or engage in a temporary business for the sale of goods,
foods, services, amusement rides, entertainment, games, or merchandise on
public or private property during special events, including the Grape Jamboree,
Geneva Winterfest, Geneva Ghoulfest and other special events approved by City
Administrators or City Council, shall obtain a permit from the City Manager or
his/her designee, before opening same and before offering for sale such sale of
goods, foods, services, amusement rides, entertainment, games, merchandise, or
property.
   (b)   Temporary Business Permit Fee.  The fee for a temporary business
permit shall be equal to the permit fees required in Section
848.02 (b).
   (c)   City approved farmer's markets shall only be required to obtain one
license to cover all vendors doing business as part of the farmer's market.
   (d)   A temporary business permit fee shall not be required for juveniles
who set up stands or tables on private property to sell goods or services for
organized fundraising purposes.
   (e)   Violations.
      (1)   Any person who violates any provisions of this section shall be
deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor on the first day of the offense, and shall
be subject to a mandatory minimum fine of eighty dollars ($80.00). Each day
upon which any such violation occurs or continues shall constitute a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree, and shall be subject to a mandatory minimum
fine of one hundred sixty dollars ($160.00) and up to thirty days in jail.
      (2)   Upon notification of a violation of any provision of this section,
the temporary business vendor must cease and desist its operations, and
dissemble and remove the temporary business operation immediately. Failure to
dissemble and remove the temporary business operation may result in additional
criminal penalties, including, but not limited to criminal trespass, littering
and/or other zoning code violations.
(Ord. 3197.  Passed 8-22-16.)
848.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
CHAPTER 856
Taxicabs
856.01   Definitions.
856.02   Operator's license required; application; inspection of vehicles.
856.03   Qualifications and responsibilities of licensees; insurance; license
fee.
856.04   Refusal of service prohibited.
856.05   Posting of rate schedule.
856.06   Prepayment requirement permitted.
856.07   License revocation.
856.08   General regulations.
856.09   Rate structure.
 
856.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Taxicab stands - see TRAF.
406.03(l),
452.10
   Operation of motor vehicles - see TRAF.
Ch. 432
   DWI; reckless operation; speed - see TRAF.
Ch. 434
   Safety and equipment - see TRAF.
Ch. 436
  856.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, unless it appears from the context that a different
meaning is intended:
   (a)   "Street" means any street, alley, avenue, court, lane or public place
in the City.
   (b)   "Taxicab" means any motor vehicle engaged in the business of carrying
persons for hire, whether the same is operated from a street stand or from a
garage, where no regular specified route is traveled, but where passengers are
taken to and from such places as they may designate, excluding automobiles used
exclusively as hearses, funeral cars, ambulances, hotel buses, sight-seeing
buses and motor buses.
(Ord. 1614.  Passed 2-26-68.)
856.02  OPERATOR'S LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; INSPECTION OF VEHICLES.
   No person shall operate or cause to be operated a taxicab for hire within
the City without first obtaining a license therefor from the City Manager.
Prior to the granting of such a license, the applicant therefor shall first
make application to the City Manager.  The City shall have the right to inspect
vehicles, financial records and personnel information of the applicant as a
part of the application to operate a taxicab.
(Ord. 2525.  Passed 2-24-97.)
856.03  QUALIFICATIONS AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF LICENSEES; INSURANCE; LICENSE
FEE.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized to grant licenses required by Section
856.02 to any citizen of the United States who is a resident of the State, at
least twenty-one years of age and of good moral character, or to any
corporation or copartnership authorized to operate taxicabs in accordance with
the laws of the State, subject to the following conditions:
   (a)   No license for the operation of taxicabs in excess of the limitation
herein prescribed shall be issued unless and until Council, by resolution,
declares that public convenience and necessity require the issuance of
additional taxicab licenses in the number set forth in such resolution. Upon
the passage of such resolution, the City Manager shall be authorized to issue
the specified additional number of licenses.  All applications must be approved
by the City Manager.
   (b)   The applicant shall file proper evidence of insurance coverage, which
shall include a copy of the policy, showing that the applicant has procured
insurance from an insurance company permitted to do business in the State,
which insurance contract guarantees the payment of any judgment against the
applicant or an individual driver of a taxicab up to one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000) for any one person and three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000) for any one accident, which insurance contract shall cover any
liability for bodily injuries or death occurring from the negligent operation
of any such taxicab.
   (c)   The applicant shall file a description of the taxicab to be operated
under such license if granted, including the maker's name, serial or VIN
number, model and year. A separate nontransferable license shall be granted for
each taxicab to be used.
   (d)   The applicant shall pay a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each taxicab to be kept and used as aforesaid for public hire, during the
license year. The license fee for part of a year shall be prorated by the month
or any part thereof. A part of a month shall be counted as a full month.
   (e)   The holder of a taxicab license must maintain at least a twelve-hour
service from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. Taxicab service
must be given to any caller who desires such service between the hours of 8:00
a.m. and 8:00 p.m.  During other hours of the day and night, the license holder
may furnish such taxi service if he or she is able to do so.
   (f)   The name of each taxicab driver and his or her commercial driver's
license (CDL) number must be registered with the Chief of Police.
   (g)   Any vehicle operated as a taxicab shall be equipped with two-way radio
communication equipment.  Each taxicab must be radio dispatched from its base
of operations.
   (h)   Any vehicle operated as a taxicab must be properly marked, including,
at a minimum, the company's name and phone number and an identification number.
(Ord. 2075.  Passed 8-27-84; Ord. 2501.  Passed 7-22-96; Ord. 2525.  Passed 2-
24-97; Ord. 3114. Passed 7-8-13.)
856.04  REFUSAL OF SERVICE PROHIBITED.
   No taxicab driver or operator shall refuse to carry any orderly person who
offers to hire such taxicab and agrees to pay the proper rate of fare.
(Ord. 1614.  Passed 2-26-68.)
856.05  POSTING OF RATE SCHEDULE.
   Every taxicab operated in the City shall have posted in it a printed
schedule of the approved rates in effect, the letters and figures of such
printed schedule to be not smaller than eleven-point type.
(Ord. 1614.  Passed 2-26-68.)
856.06  PREPAYMENT REQUIREMENT PERMITTED.
   Every driver of a public taxicab shall have the right to demand the legal
fare in advance and may refuse employment unless so prepaid, but no driver of a
public taxicab shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person
upon request anywhere in the City, unless previously engaged.
(Ord. 1614.  Passed 2-26-68.)
856.07  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Council, by a two-thirds vote of all members elected thereto, may direct the
City Manager to revoke any license issued under this chapter for any of the
following reasons:
   (a)   A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by the licensee;
   (b)   The conviction of a licensee of a felony;
   (c)   The conviction of a licensee of four or more misdemeanors, or the
conviction of a licensee of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or
   (d)   Failure of a licensee to discharge any taxicab driver who has been
declared by Council, by a vote of two-thirds of the members elected thereto, to
be unfit to drive a taxicab. The licensee shall have ten days to discharge such
a driver, after having been notified in writing by the City Manager of the
aforesaid declaration of Council.
(Ord. 1614.  Passed 2-26-68.)
856.08  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   No person shall:
   (a)   Drive a taxicab while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a
drug of abuse, or use or drink any intoxicating liquor or drug of abuse while
engaged in operating such taxicab;
   (b)   Drive a taxicab who is under the age of twenty-one;
   (c)   Use any portion of a public street or alley as a taxicab stand, except
for such time as is necessary to load or unload passengers, except in such
portion of the street or alley as has been designated by Council as a taxicab
stand;
   (d)   Operate any vehicle that does not meet Ohio Safety Inspections;
   (e)   Operate more than the number of taxicabs specified in the application
for a license under Section
856.02 or operate taxicabs in excess of the number authorized by Council; or
   (f)   Operate a taxicab found to be unsafe by the City Manager after
receiving notice in writing that such taxicab is unsafe.
(Ord. 2525.  Passed 2-24-97.)
856.09  RATE STRUCTURE.
   (a)   The rate structure for taxicabs shall be as follows:
      (1)   The minimum charge for any taxicab ride is two dollars and fifty
cents ($2.50).
      (2)   There shall be no charge for parcels or baggage. There shall be a
waiting time charge of ten cents (10¢) per minute for each minute or fraction
thereof after the first five minutes.
      (3)   There shall be a charge of twelve dollars ($12.00) an hour plus
waiting time charges for the lease of a car and driver.
   (b)   The fares established in subsection (a) hereof shall be posted in all
taxicabs.
(Ord. 2501.  Passed 7-22-96; Ord. 2525.  Passed 2-24-97.)
856.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
CHAPTER 858
Video Service Providers
858.01   Video service provider fees required.
858.02   City Manager to provide written notice of fees.
858.01  VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEES REQUIRED.
   In accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 1332.32, all video service
providers providing video service in the City pursuant to a video service
authorization obtained from the Director of the Ohio Department of Commerce
shall pay Video Service Provider Fees ("VSP Fees") in the amount of five
percent (5%) of gross revenues received from providing video service in the
City, which gross revenue base shall include advertising revenues. The VSP Fee
shall be paid quarterly, not sooner than 45 days nor later than 60 days after
the end of each calendar quarter.
(Ord. 2949.  Passed 11-12-07.)
858.02  CITY MANAGER TO PROVIDE WRITTEN NOTICE OF FEES.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed, upon receipt of notice
from a video service provider that it will begin providing video service in the
City pursuant to a state-issued video service authorization, to provide such
video service provider with written notice of the VSP Fee as determined by this
Council above, which notice may be given by overnight mail (return receipt),
certified mail, or other manner of delivery, no later than ten days from
receipt of the provider's notice.
(Ord. 2949.  Passed 11-12-07.)
